intro: Styphelia capillaris, commonly known as the slender snowbell, is a low-growing evergreen shrub native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its small, bell-shaped white flowers. The plant typically thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and prefers shaded to partially shaded environments. Its foliage consists of narrow, grass-like leaves that remain green throughout the year. Styphelia capillaris is often found in moist, sandy soils along the edges of swamps and in pine forests.
